css-scrollbar.title: CSS scrollbar styling
css-scrollbar.description: Methods of styling scrollbars' color and width.

links.title: Webkit blog post describing their non-standard support

notes_by_num.1: Only supports styling scrollbar colors through proprietary prefixed properties, no other properties to define the scrollbar's appearance. (not on standards track)
notes_by_num.2: Supports scrollbar styling via CSS [pseudo-properties](https://webkit.org/blog/363/styling-scrollbars/). (not on standards track)
notes_by_num.3: Scrollbar styling doesn’t work in [WKWebView](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CB-10123)
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled by setting the layout.css.scrollbar-colors.enabled and layout.css.scrollbar-width.enabled flags to true.
notes_by_num.5: Firefox 63 supported scrollbar-face-color and scrollbar-track-color seperate properties (now dropped from the spec) instead of unified scrollbar-color property.
notes_by_num.6: Firefox neither supports `light` and `dark` values of scrollbar-color nor `<length>` values of scrollbar width

css-sel2.title: CSS 2.1 selectors
css-sel2.description: Basic CSS selectors including: `*` (universal selector), `>` (child selector), `:first-child`, `:link`, `:visited`, `:active`, `:hover`, `:focus`, `:lang()`, `+` (adjacent sibling selector), `[attr]`, `[attr="val"]`, `[attr~="val"]`, `[attr|="bar"]`, `.foo` (class selector), `#foo` (id selector)
css-sel2.notes: Support for `:visited` styling [varies across browsers](http://sixrevisions.com/css/visited-pseudo-class-strange/) due to security concerns.

css-sel3.title: CSS3 selectors
css-sel3.description: Advanced element selection using selectors including: `[foo^="bar"]`, `[foo$="bar"]`, `[foo*="bar"]`, `:root`, `:nth-child()`,  `:nth-last-child()`, `:nth-of-type()`, `:nth-last-of-type()`, `:last-child`, `:first-of-type`, `:last-of-type`, `:only-child`, `:only-of-type`, `:empty`, `:target`, `:enabled`, `:disabled`, `:checked`, `:not()`, `~` (general sibling)

notes_by_num.1: IE7 and IE8 support only these CSS3 selectors: General siblings (`element1~element2`) and Attribute selectors `[attr^=val]`, `[attr$=val]`, and `[attr*=val]`

css-selection.title: ::selection CSS pseudo-element
css-selection.description: The ::selection CSS pseudo-element applies rules to the portion of a document that has been highlighted (e.g., selected with the mouse or another pointing device) by the user.

css-shapes.title: CSS Shapes Level 1
css-shapes.description: Allows geometric shapes to be set in CSS to define an area for text to flow around. Includes properties `shape-outside`, `shape-margin` and `shape-image-threshold`

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Partially supported in Firefox by enabling "layout.css.shape-outside.enabled" in about:config

css-snappoints.title: CSS Scroll Snap
css-snappoints.description: CSS technique that allows customizable scrolling experiences like pagination of carousels by setting defined snap positions.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - CSS Scroll snap points
Polyfill - based on an [older version](https://www.w3.org/TR/2015/WD-css-snappoints-1-20150326/) of the spec
Polyfill - based on the [current version](https://www.w3.org/TR/css-scroll-snap-1/) of the spec
MDN Web Docs - CSS Scroll Snap
A CSS Snap Points based carousel (and lightweight polyfill)

css-snappoints.notes: Works in the iOS WKWebView, but not UIWebView.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE10 refers to support limited to touch screens.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE11 [documented here](https://web.archive.org/web/20160616212557/https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/444684/openwebref/CSS/scroll-snap-points/support.html)
notes_by_num.4: Partial support in Safari refers to not supporting the `none` keyword in `scroll-snap-points-x`, `scroll-snap-points-y` and `scroll-snap-coordinate`, and length keywords (`top`, `right`, etc.) in `scroll-snap-destination` and `scroll-snap-coordinate`.
notes_by_num.5: Supports properties from an [older version](https://www.w3.org/TR/2015/WD-css-snappoints-1-20150326/) of the spec.
notes_by_num.6: Partial support in IE & Edge refers to not supporting `scroll-snap-coordinate` and `scroll-snap-destination`.
notes_by_num.7: Available behind the "Experimental Web Platform features" feature flag

css-sticky.title: CSS position:sticky
css-sticky.description: Keeps elements positioned as "fixed" or "relative" depending on how it appears in the viewport. As a result the element is "stuck" when necessary while scrolling.
css-sticky.notes: Any ancestor between the sticky element and its user-scrollable container with overflow computed as anything but `visible`/`clip` will effectively prevent sticking behavior.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox by setting the about:config preference layout.css.sticky.enabled to true
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag
notes_by_num.3: Not supported on any `table` parts - See [Firefox bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=975644)
notes_by_num.4: Supported on `th` elements, but not `thead` or `tr` - See [Chrome bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=702927)
notes_by_num.5: Do not appear to support sticky table headers
notes_by_num.6: Supported on `th` elements, but not `thead` or `tr` - See [Edge bug](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/16765952/)

css-subgrid.title: CSS Subgrid
css-subgrid.description: Feature of the CSS Grid Layout Module Level 2 that allows a grid-item with its own grid to align in one or both dimensions with its parent grid.

links.title: CSS Grid Level 2: Here Comes Subgrid

css-supports-api.title: CSS.supports() API
css-supports-api.description: The CSS.supports() static methods returns a Boolean value indicating if the browser supports a given CSS feature, or not.

links.title: Native CSS Feature Detection via the @supports Rule

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Presto-based Opera browsers refers to using an older API (`window.supportsCSS`)
notes_by_num.2: Does not support parentheses-less one-argument version.

css-table.title: CSS Table display
css-table.description: Method of displaying elements as tables, rows, and cells. Includes support for all `display: table-*` properties as well as `display: inline-table`

notes_by_num.1: Firefox 2 does not support `inline-table`

css-text-align-last.title: CSS3 text-align-last
css-text-align-last.description: CSS property to describe how the last line of a block or a line right before a forced line break when `text-align` is `justify`.

notes_by_num.1: In Internet Explorer, the start and end values are not supported.
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "Enable Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.3: Enabled through the "Enable Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in opera://flags

css-text-indent.title: CSS text-indent
css-text-indent.description: The `text-indent` property applies indentation to lines of inline content in a block.

links.title: Article on using text-indent for image replacement

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to supporting a `<length>` value, but not the `each-line` or `hanging` keywords.
notes_by_num.2: Support for `each-line` & `hanging` is available behind the Experimental Web Platform features flag

css-text-justify.title: CSS text-justify
css-text-justify.description: CSS property to define how text should be justified when `text-align: justify` is set.

notes_by_num.1: Supports `inter-word`, but not `inter-character` or  `none`. Also supports the following unofficial values: `distribute` , `distribute-all-lines`, `distribute-center-last`, `inter-cluster`, `inter-ideograph`, `newspaper`. See [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/text-justify) for details.
notes_by_num.2: `inter-word` and `distribute` values supported behind the "Experimental platform features" flag but `distribute` support [is buggy](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=467406)
notes_by_num.3: Behind the "layout.css.text-justify.enabled" flag
notes_by_num.4: Supports `auto`, `none`, `inter-word`, `inter-character`, and `distribute` with the exact same meaning and behavior as `inter-character` for legacy reasons.

css-text-orientation.title: CSS text-orientation
css-text-orientation.description: The CSS `text-orientation` property specifies the orientation of text within a line. Current values only have an effect in vertical typographic modes (defined with the `writing-mode` property)

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled on firefox via the 'layout.css.vertical-text.enabled' flag in about:config.

css-textshadow.title: CSS3 Text-shadow
css-textshadow.description: Method of applying one or more shadow or blur effects to text
css-textshadow.notes: Opera Mini ignores the blur-radius set, so no blur effect is visible. Text-shadow behavior can be somewhat emulated in older IE versions using the non-standard "dropshadow" or "glow" filters.

notes_by_num.1: IE 10+ supports a fourth length value for the shadow's "spread". This is not (yet) part of the specification.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari 3.* refers to not supporting multiple shadows.

css-touch-action.title: CSS touch-action property
css-touch-action.description: touch-action is a CSS property that controls filtering of gesture events, providing developers with a declarative mechanism to selectively disable touch scrolling (in one or both axes) or double-tap-zooming.

links.title: What Exactly Is..... The 300ms Click Delay
What Exactly Is..... The 300ms Click Delay (Chinese)
WebKit bug 149854: Implement touch-action: manipulation; for iOS
WebKit bug 133112: touch-action CSS property support

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox behind the `layout.css.touch_action.enabled` flag, Firefox for Windows 8 Touch ('Metro') enabled by default.
notes_by_num.2: IE10+ has already supported these property which are not in standard at present such as `double-tap-zoom`, `cross-slide-x`, `cross-slide-y`.
notes_by_num.3: iOS Safari only supports `auto` and `manipulation`.
notes_by_num.4: Not applicable to Firefox platforms that support neither pointer nor touch events.

css-transitions.title: CSS3 Transitions
css-transitions.description: Simple method of animating certain properties of an element, with ability to define property, duration, delay and timing function.

links.title: Animation of property types support in Opera

css-transitions.notes: Support listed is for `transition` properties as well as the `transitionend` event.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the `steps()`, `step-start` & `step-end` timing functions

css-unset-value.title: CSS unset value
css-unset-value.description: A CSS value that's the same as "inherit" if a property is inherited or "initial" if a property is not inherited.

links.title: WebKit bug 148614: Add support for the `unset` CSS property value

css-variables.title: CSS Variables (Custom Properties)
css-variables.description: Permits the declaration and usage of cascading variables in stylesheets.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Using CSS variables

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in `chrome://flags`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support is due to bugs present (see known issues)
notes_by_num.3: Partial support is due to bugs present (see known issues)

css-when-else.title: CSS @when / @else conditional rules
css-when-else.description: Syntax allowing CSS conditions (like media and support queries) to be written more simply, as well as making it possibly to write mutually exclusive rules using `@else` statements.

links.title: Blog post: Extending CSS when/else chains: A first look

css-widows-orphans.title: CSS widows & orphans
css-widows-orphans.description: CSS properties to control when lines break across pages or columns by defining the amount of lines that must be left before or after the break.
css-widows-orphans.notes: Some older WebKit-based browsers recognize the properties, but do not appear to have actual support

notes_by_num.1: Supports widows & orphans properties, but due to not supporting CSS multi-columns the support is only for page breaks (for print)

css-writing-mode.title: CSS writing-mode property
css-writing-mode.description: Property to define whether lines of text are laid out horizontally or vertically and the direction in which blocks progress.

notes_by_num.1: Internet Explorer supports different values from an [earlier version of the spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/2003/CR-css3-text-20030514/#Progression), which originated from SVG.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Firefox under the `layout.css.vertical-text.enabled` flag

css-zoom.title: CSS zoom

links.title: Article explaining usage of zoom as the hack for fixing rendering bugs in IE6 and IE7.

css-zoom.notes: Originally implemented only in Internet Explorer. Although several other browsers support the property, using `transform: scale()` is the recommended solution to scale content. Note though that `transform: scale()` does not work the same as `zoom`. If e.g. `transform: scale(0.6)` is used on the `html` or `body` element then it resizes the entire page, showing a minified page with huge white margins around it, whereas `zoom: 0.6` scales the *elements* on the page, but not the page itself on which the elements are drawn.

notes_by_num.1: The `-ms-zoom` property is an extension to CSS, and can be used as a synonym for `zoom` in IE8 Standards mode.

css3-attr.title: CSS3 attr() function for all properties
css3-attr.description: While `attr()` is supported for effectively all browsers for the `content` property, CSS Values and Units Level 3 adds the ability to use `attr()` on **any** CSS property, and to use it for non-string values (e.g. numbers, colors).

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
Mozilla Bug #435426: implement css3-values extensions to `attr()`
Chromium issue #246571: Implement CSS3 attribute / attr references
WebKit Bug #26609: Support CSS3 attr() function

css3-attr.notes: See the [generated content](/#feat=css-gencontent) table for support for `attr()` for the `content` property.

css3-boxsizing.title: CSS3 Box-sizing
css3-boxsizing.description: Method of specifying whether or not an element's borders and padding should be included in size units
css3-boxsizing.notes: Firefox versions before 57 also supported the `padding-box` value for `box-sizing`, though this value was been removed from the specification and later versions of the browser.

css3-colors.title: CSS3 Colors
css3-colors.description: Method of describing colors using Hue, Saturation and Lightness (hsl()) rather than just RGB, as well as allowing alpha-transparency with rgba() and hsla().

css3-cursors.title: CSS3 Cursors (original values)
css3-cursors.description: CSS3 cursor values added in the 2004 spec, including none, context-menu, cell, vertical-text, alias, copy, no-drop, not-allowed, nesw-resize, nwse-resize, col-resize, row-resize and all-scroll.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to no support for the alias, cell, copy, ew-resize, ns-resize, nesw-resize, nwse-resize or context-menu cursors.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting 'none'.

css3-cursors-grab.title: CSS grab & grabbing cursors
css3-cursors-grab.description: Support for the `grab` & `grabbing` values for the `cursor` property. Used to indicate that something can be grabbed (dragged to be moved).

css3-cursors-newer.title: CSS3 Cursors: zoom-in & zoom-out
css3-cursors-newer.description: Support for `zoom-in`, `zoom-out` values for the CSS3 `cursor` property.

css3-tabsize.title: CSS3 tab-size
css3-tabsize.description: Method of customizing the width of the tab character. Only effective using 'white-space: pre' or 'white-space: pre-wrap'.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Partial refers to supporting `<integer>` but not `<length>` values.

currentcolor.title: CSS currentColor value
currentcolor.description: A CSS value that will apply the existing `color` value to other properties like `background-color`, etc.

custom-elements.title: Custom Elements (deprecated V0 spec)
custom-elements.description: Original V0 version of the custom elements specification. See [Custom Elements V1](#feat=custom-elementsv1) for support for the latest version.

links.title: HTML5Rocks - Custom Elements: defining new elements in HTML
Google Developers - Custom elements v1: reusable web components

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "dom.webcomponents.enabled" preference in about:config
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "dom.webcomponents.customelements.enabled" preference in about:config

custom-elementsv1.title: Custom Elements (V1)
custom-elementsv1.description: One of the key features of the Web Components system, custom elements allow new HTML tags to be defined.

links.title: Firefox tracking bug: Implement Custom Elements (from Web Components)
IE Web Platform Status and Roadmap: Custom Elements
Google Developers - Custom elements v1: reusable web components

notes_by_num.1: Supports "Autonomous custom elements" but not "Customized built-in elements" see [WebKit bug 182671](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=182671).
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the `dom.webcomponents.enabled` preference in `about:config`.
notes_by_num.3: Enabled through the `dom.webcomponents.customelements.enabled` preference in `about:config`.

customevent.title: CustomEvent
customevent.description: A DOM event interface that can carry custom application-defined data.

links.title: Polyfill based on the MDN snippet
EventListener polyfill which includes a CustomEvent polyfill

customevent.notes: Not supported in some versions of Android's old WebKit-based WebView.

notes_by_num.1: While a `window.CustomEvent` object exists, it cannot be called as a constructor. Instead of `new CustomEvent(...)`, you must use `e = document.createEvent('CustomEvent')` and then `e.initCustomEvent(...)`
notes_by_num.2: There is no `window.CustomEvent` object, but `document.createEvent('CustomEvent')` still works.

datalist.title: Datalist element
datalist.description: Method of setting a list of options for a user to select in a text field, while leaving the ability to enter a custom value.

links.title: Minimal and library dependency-free vanilla JavaScript polyfill

datalist.notes: While most commonly used on text fields, datalists can also be used on other input types. IE11 supports the element on `range` fields. Chrome and Opera also support datalists to suggest given values on `range`, `color` and date/time fields.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to [a bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=773041) where long lists of items are unscrollable resulting in unselectable options.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE refers to [significantly buggy behavior](https://web.archive.org/web/20170121011936/http://playground.onereason.eu/2013/04/ie10s-lousy-support-for-datalists/) (IE11+ does send the input and change events upon selection).
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to no support for datalists on non-text fields (e.g. number, [range](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=841942), [color](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=960984)).
notes_by_num.4: Partial support in Edge refers [to disappearing option elements on focusing the input element via tab](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/20066595/).
notes_by_num.5: Supported through WKWebView and Safari but not through UIWebView
notes_by_num.6: In Firefox, autocomplete must be set to off to make dynamic datalist work due to [a bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1474137)

dataset.title: dataset & data-* attributes
dataset.description: Method of applying and accessing custom data to elements.

links.title: MS Edge UserVoice #15885483: Support dataset and data attributes on SVG elements

dataset.notes:
Partial support refers to being able to use `data-*` attributes and access them using `getAttribute`. 

"Supported" refers to accessing the values using the `dataset` property. Current spec only refers to support on HTML elements, only some browsers also have support for SVG/MathML elements.

notes_by_num.1: While the HTML spec doesn't require it, these browsers also support `dataset` and `data-*` attributes on SVG elements, in compliance with [current plans for SVG2](https://www.w3.org/2015/01/15-svg-minutes.html#item03)

datauri.title: Data URIs
datauri.description: Method of embedding images and other files in webpages as a string of text, generally using base64 encoding.

notes_by_num.1: Support is limited to images and linked resources like CSS files, not HTML or JS files. Max URI length is 32KB.
notes_by_num.2: Support is limited to images and linked resources like CSS or JS, not HTML files. Maximum size limit is 4GB.
notes_by_num.3: SVGs with XML declarations are not displayed when used in data-urls

date-tolocaledatestring.title: Date.prototype.toLocaleDateString
date-tolocaledatestring.description: Date method to generate a language sensitive representation of a given date, formatted based on a specified locale and options.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the `locale` or `options` parameters
notes_by_num.2: Does not support all locales correctly
notes_by_num.3: Does not support the `timeZone` option

decorators.title: Decorators
decorators.description: ECMAScript Decorators are an in-progress proposal for extending JavaScript classes. Decorators use a special syntax, prefixed with an `@` symbol and placed immediately before the code being extended.

links.title: JavaScript Decorators: What They Are and When to Use Them
A minimal guide to JavaScript (ECMAScript) Decorators and Property Descriptor of the Object

decorators.notes: While not yet supported natively in browsers, decorators are supported by a number of transpiler tools.
decorators.keywords: es7 decorators,JavaScript Class and Property Decorators

details.title: Details & Summary elements
details.description: The <details> element generates a simple no-JavaScript widget to show/hide element contents, optionally by clicking on its child <summary> element.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Firefox through the `dom.details_element.enabled` flag
notes_by_num.2: 'toggle' event is not supported
notes_by_num.3: <summary> is not keyboard accessible
notes_by_num.4: Some versions of Safari display smaller font-size than intended when using `rem` units with system fonts. (See: https://colloq.io/blog/safaris-detailssummary-rem-font-size-issue)

deviceorientation.title: DeviceOrientation & DeviceMotion events
deviceorientation.description: API for detecting orientation and motion events from the device running the browser.
deviceorientation.notes: Partial support refers to the lack of compassneedscalibration event. Partial support also refers to the lack of devicemotion event support for Chrome 30- and Opera. Opera Mobile 14 lost the ondevicemotion event support. Firefox 3.6, 4 and 5 support the non-standard [MozOrientation](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/DOM/MozOrientation) event.

notes_by_num.1: `compassneedscalibration` supported in IE11 only for compatible devices with Windows 8.1+.

devicepixelratio.title: Window.devicePixelRatio
devicepixelratio.description: Read-only property that returns the ratio of the (vertical) size of one physical pixel on the current display device to the size of one CSS pixel.
devicepixelratio.notes: As the page is zoomed in the number of device pixels that one CSS pixel covers increases, and therefore the value of devicePixelRatio will also increase.

dialog.title: Dialog element
dialog.description: Method of easily creating custom dialog boxes to display to the user with modal or non-modal options. Also includes a `::backdrop` pseudo-element for behind the element.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox by enabling `dom.dialog_element.enabled` in `about:config`
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in `chrome://flags`
notes_by_num.3: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in `opera://flags`
notes_by_num.4: Enabled by default in Firefox Nightly only

dispatchevent.title: EventTarget.dispatchEvent
dispatchevent.description: Method to programmatically trigger a DOM event.

notes_by_num.1: Supports Microsoft's proprietary [`EventTarget.fireEvent() method`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/fireEvent).

dnssec.title: DNSSEC and DANE
dnssec.description: Method of validating a DNS response against a trusted root server. Mitigates various attacks that could reroute a user to a fake site while showing the real URL for the original site.
dnssec.notes:
Browsers have generally decided to not implement DNSSEC validation because the added complexity outweighs the improvements to the browser. DNSSEC is still useful as it is widely used to protect delivery of records between DNS servers, only failing to protect the delivery from the last DNS server to the browser.

[Certificate transparency](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Certificate_Transparency) is widely used and tries to provide the same security as DNSSEC but by very different means.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support DNSSEC but still benefits greatly from it, as most of the security improvements are gained in the DNS-network and not in the browser.
notes_by_num.2: Early versions of Chrome [experimented](https://www.imperialviolet.org/2011/06/16/dnssecchrome.html) with browser-level validation.

dnssec.keywords: DNS Security Extensions,Domain Name System Security Extensions,DNS based Authentication of Named Entities

do-not-track.title: Do Not Track API
do-not-track.description: Allows the browser's Do Not Track setting to be queried via `navigator.doNotTrack`.
do-not-track.notes: Partial support refers to the doNotTrack field being misnamed, or being attached to an object other than `navigator` (e.g. `window`).

notes_by_num.1: IE 9 and 10 are vendor-prefixed as `navigator.msDoNotTrack`
notes_by_num.2: IE 11 and Edge 16- use `window.doNotTrack` instead of `navigator.doNotTrack`.
notes_by_num.3: Browsers based on Gecko versions prior to 32 used 'yes' and 'no' rather than '1' and '0'.
notes_by_num.4: Between versions 6.1.1 and 9.1.3, Safari supported an ultimately-rejected amendment to the spec, using `window.doNotTrack` rather than `navigator.doNotTrack`.

document-currentscript.title: document.currentScript
document-currentscript.description: `document.currentScript` returns the `<script>` element whose script is currently being processed.

document-evaluate-xpath.title: document.evaluate & XPath
document-evaluate-xpath.description: Allow nodes in an XML/HTML document to be traversed using XPath expressions.

document-execcommand.title: Document.execCommand()
document-execcommand.description: Allows running commands to manipulate the contents of an editable region in a document switched to designMode
document-execcommand.notes: To determine what commands are supported, see `Document.queryCommandSupported()`

document-policy.title: Document Policy
document-policy.description: A mechanism that allows developers to set certain rules and policies for a given site. The rules can change default browser behaviour, block certain features or set limits on resource usage. Document Policy is useful both for security and performance, and is similar to [Permissions Policy](/permissions-policy).

links.title: Chromium tracking bug for new policies

document-policy.notes: Standard support includes the HTTP `Document-Policy` header and `policy` attribute on iframes.

notes_by_num.1: Chromium browsers only support the HTTP header.

document-scrollingelement.title: document.scrollingElement
document-scrollingelement.description: `document.scrollingElement` refers to the element that scrolls the document.

documenthead.title: document.head
documenthead.description: Convenience property for accessing the `<head>` element

dom-manip-convenience.title: DOM manipulation convenience methods
dom-manip-convenience.description: jQuery-like methods on DOM nodes to insert nodes around or within a node, or to replace one node with another. These methods accept any number of DOM nodes or HTML strings as arguments. Includes: `ChildNode.before`, `ChildNode.after`, `ChildNode.replaceWith`, `ParentNode.prepend`, and `ParentNode.append`.

links.title: MS Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "Enable Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in chrome://flags

dom-range.title: Document Object Model Range
dom-range.description: A contiguous range of content in a Document, DocumentFragment or Attr

links.title: "Rangy" Range library with old IE support

domcontentloaded.title: DOMContentLoaded
domcontentloaded.description: JavaScript event that fires when the DOM is loaded, but before all page assets are loaded (CSS, images, etc.).

dommatrix.title: DOMMatrix
dommatrix.description: The `DOMMatrix` interface represents 4x4 matrices, suitable for 2D and 3D operations. Supersedes the `WebKitCSSMatrix` and `SVGMatrix` interfaces.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the `WebKitCSSMatrix` version of the interface, not `DOMMatrix`
notes_by_num.2: `WebKitCSSMatrix#skewX`, `WebKitCSSMatrix#skewY` are not supported
notes_by_num.3: Only supports the `DOMMatrix` version of the interface, not `WebKitCSSMatrix` (support required by spec for legacy reasons)
notes_by_num.4: Only replaces `WebkitCSSMatrix` and not `SVGMatrix`
notes_by_num.5: Does not support `fromMatrix()`, `fromFloat32Array()`, `fromFloat64Array()`, and `toJSON()` methods

download.title: Download attribute
download.description: When used on an anchor, this attribute signifies that the browser should download the resource the anchor points to rather than navigate to it.

links.title: Demo: creating a text file and downloading it.

dragndrop.title: Drag and Drop
dragndrop.description: Method of easily dragging and dropping elements on a page, requiring minimal JavaScript.

links.title: Microsoft Edge setDragImage feature request on UserVoice

dragndrop.notes:
`dataTransfer.items` only supported by Chrome.

Currently no browser supports the `dropzone` attribute.

Firefox supports any kind of DOM elements for `.setDragImage`. Chrome must have either an `HTMLImageElement` or any kind of DOM Element attached to the DOM _and within the viewport_ of the browser for `.setDragImage`.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to no support for the `dataTransfer.files` or `.types` objects
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting `.setDragImage`
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to limited supported formats for `dataTransfer.setData`/`getData`.
notes_by_num.4: Not supported in Chromium browsers on Android 6 or older.

element-closest.title: Element.closest()
element-closest.description: DOM method that returns the current element if it matches the given selector, or else the closest ancestor element that matches the given selector, or else null.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

element-from-point.title: document.elementFromPoint()
element-from-point.description: Given coordinates for a point relative to the viewport, returns the element that a click event would be dispatched at if the user were to click the point (in other words, the element that hit-testing would find).

element-scroll-methods.title: Scroll methods on elements (scroll, scrollTo, scrollBy)
element-scroll-methods.description: Methods to change the scroll position of an element. Similar to setting `scrollTop` & `scrollLeft` properties, but also allows options to be passed to define the scroll behavior.
element-scroll-methods.notes: See also the support for the [`scrollIntoView` method](/#feat=scrollintoview).

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the `smooth` behavior option.

eme.title: Encrypted Media Extensions
eme.description: The EncryptedMediaExtenstions API provides interfaces for controlling the playback of content which is subject to a DRM scheme.

links.title: Encrypted Media Extensions API on MDN

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the older event-based specification

eot.title: EOT - Embedded OpenType fonts
eot.description: Type of font that can be derived from a regular font, allowing small files and legal use of high-quality fonts. Usage is restricted by the file being tied to the website
eot.notes: Proposal by Microsoft, being considered for W3C standardization.

es5.title: ECMAScript 5
es5.description: Full support for the ECMAScript 5 specification. Features include `Function.prototype.bind`, Array methods like `indexOf`, `forEach`, `map` & `filter`, Object methods like `defineProperty`, `create` & `keys`, the `trim` method on Strings and many more.

links.title: Polyfill for all possible ES5 features is available in the core-js library

es5.notes: As the specification includes many JavaScript features, un-numbered partial support varies widely and is shown in detail on the [ECMAScript 5 compatibility tables](http://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es5/) by Kangax.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `parseInt()` ignoring leading zeros.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support Strict mode
notes_by_num.3: Does not support zero-width chars in identifiers & Immutable `undefined`
notes_by_num.4: IE8 has virtually no ES5 support, but does support `Object.defineProperty`, `Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor`, JSON parsing & Property access on strings

es6.title: ECMAScript 2015 (ES6)
es6.description: Support for the ECMAScript 2015 specification. Features include Promises, Modules, Classes, Template Literals, Arrow Functions, Let and Const, Default Parameters, Generators, Destructuring Assignment, Rest & Spread, Map/Set & WeakMap/WeakSet and many more.

links.title: ES6 New features: overview and comparisons
Polyfill for all possible ES2015 features is available in the core-js library

es6.notes: As ES6 refers to a huge specification and browsers have various levels of support, "Supported" means at least 95% of the spec is supported. "Partial support" refers to at least 10% of the spec being supported. For full details see the [Kangax ES6 support table](https://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/).

notes_by_num.1: Notable partial support in IE11 includes (at least some) support for `const`, `let`, block-level function declaration, typed arrays, `Map`, `Set` and `WeakMap`.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support [tail call optimization](https://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/#test-proper_tail_calls_%28tail_call_optimisation%29)
notes_by_num.3: Only has partial Symbol support and partial support for `RegExp.prototype` properties

es6-class.title: ES6 classes
es6-class.description: ES6 classes are syntactical sugar to provide a much simpler and clearer syntax to create objects and deal with inheritance.

links.title: Sitepoint deep dive on ES6 classes
List of resources critical of ES6 classes

notes_by_num.1: Requires strict mode. Non-strict mode support is behind the flag 'Enable Experimental JavaScript', disabled by default.

es6-generators.title: ES6 Generators
es6-generators.description: ES6 Generators are special functions that can be used to control the iteration behavior of a loop. Generators are defined using a `function*` declaration.

es6-module.title: JavaScript modules via script tag
es6-module.description: Loading JavaScript module scripts (aka ES6 modules) using `<script type="module">` Includes support for the `nomodule` attribute.

links.title: Blog post: Native ECMAScript modules - the first overview
Counterpart ECMAScript specification for import/export syntax
Will it double-fetch? Browser behavior with `module` / `nomodule` scripts

notes_by_num.1: Support can be enabled via `about:flags`
notes_by_num.2: Support can be enabled via `about:config`
notes_by_num.3: Support can be enabled via the `experimental-web-platform-features` flag
notes_by_num.4: Does not support the `nomodule` attribute
notes_by_num.5: A [polyfill is available](https://gist.github.com/samthor/64b114e4a4f539915a95b91ffd340acc) for Safari 10.1/iOS Safari 10.3
notes_by_num.6: `nomodule` scripts are not executed, but they're still fetched

es6-module-dynamic-import.title: JavaScript modules: dynamic import()
es6-module-dynamic-import.description: Loading JavaScript modules dynamically using the import() syntax

links.title: Counterpart ECMAScript specification for import() syntax
Blog post: Native ECMAScript modules - dynamic import()

notes_by_num.1: Support can be enabled via `javascript.options.dynamicImport` flag. See [bug 1517546](https://bugzil.la/1517546).

es6-number.title: ES6 Number
es6-number.description: Extensions to the `Number` built-in object in ES6, including constant properties `EPSILON`, `MIN_SAFE_INTEGER`, and `MAX_SAFE_INTEGER`, and methods ` isFinite`, `isInteger`, `isSafeInteger`, and `isNaN`.

links.title: New number and Math features in ES6
Polyfill for those features is available in the core-js library

notes_by_num.1: Partial refers to only supporting the `isFinite`, `isInteger`, and `isNaN` methods.
notes_by_num.2: Partial refers to supporting the same as #1 and the addition of the `EPSILON` property.
notes_by_num.3: Partial refers to supporting all new features except the `isSafeInteger` method.
notes_by_num.4: Partial refers to only supporting the `isFinite` and `isNaN` methods.

es6-string-includes.title: String.prototype.includes
es6-string-includes.description: The includes() method determines whether one string may be found within another string, returning true or false as appropriate.

links.title: Polyfill for this feature is available in the core-js library

eventsource.title: Server-sent events
eventsource.description: Method of continuously sending data from a server to the browser, rather than repeatedly requesting it (EventSource interface, used to fall under HTML5)

extended-system-fonts.title: ui-serif, ui-sans-serif, ui-monospace and ui-rounded values for font-family
extended-system-fonts.description: Allows more control when choosing system interface fonts

feature-policy.title: Feature Policy
feature-policy.description: This specification defines a mechanism that allows developers to selectively enable and disable use of various browser features and APIs. Feature Policy is deprecated and has been replaced with [Permissions Policy](/permissions-policy) and [Document Policy](/document-policy).
feature-policy.notes: Standard support includes the HTTP `Feature-Policy` header, `allow` attribute on iframes and the `document.featurePolicy` JS API.

notes_by_num.1: Older Chromium browsers did not support the JS API.
notes_by_num.2: Safari and Firefox only supports the `allow` attribute on iframes.
notes_by_num.3: Safari doesn't support a [list of origins](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=189901) or a [wildcard](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=187816).
notes_by_num.4: At least partially supports [Permissions Policy](/permissions-policy), the main replacement for this spec.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support can be enabled in Firefox with the `dom.fetch.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Only available in Chrome and Opera within ServiceWorkers.
notes_by_num.3: Available in Chrome and Opera within Window and Workers by enabling the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in `chrome://flags`
notes_by_num.4: Firefox <40 is not completely conforming to the specs and does not respect the <base> tag for relative URIs in fetch requests. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1161625
notes_by_num.5: Appears to exist in Safari Technology Preview but does not work in current build. Should work in [next preview build](https://twitter.com/xeenon/status/715379838081576960)

fieldset-disabled.title: disabled attribute of the fieldset element
fieldset-disabled.description: Allows disabling all of the form control descendants of a fieldset via a `disabled` attribute on the fieldset element itself.

notes_by_num.1: Text inputs that are descendants of a disabled fieldset appear disabled but the user can still interact with them. [See IE bug #962368.](https://web.archive.org/web/20170306075528/https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedbackdetail/view/962368/can-still-edit-input-type-text-within-fieldset-disabled)
notes_by_num.2: File inputs that are descendants of a disabled fieldset appear disabled but the user can still interact with them. [See IE bug #817488.](https://web.archive.org/web/20170306075531/https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedbackdetail/view/817488)

fileapi.title: File API
fileapi.description: Method of manipulating file objects in web applications client-side, as well as programmatically selecting them and accessing their data.

notes_by_num.1: Does not have `FileReader` support.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support the `File` constructor

filereader.title: FileReader API
filereader.description: Method of reading the contents of a File or Blob object into memory

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `readAsBinaryString`, but `readAsBinaryString` [can be polyfilled](https://stackoverflow.com/q/31391207)

filereadersync.title: FileReaderSync
filereadersync.description: Allows files to be read synchronously in Web Workers

filesystem.title: Filesystem & FileWriter API
filesystem.description: Method of reading and writing files to a sandboxed file system.
filesystem.notes: The File API: Directories and System specification is no longer being maintained and support may be dropped in future versions.

flac.title: FLAC audio format
flac.notes: Support refers to this format's use in the `audio` element, not other conditions.

notes_by_num.1: HTMLMediaElement.canPlayType('audio/flac') returns an empty string
notes_by_num.2: Only works on ChromeOS
notes_by_num.3: Supported only on macOS High Sierra or later

flexbox.title: CSS Flexible Box Layout Module
flexbox.description: Method of positioning elements in horizontal or vertical stacks. Support includes all properties prefixed with `flex`, as well as `display: flex`, `display: inline-flex`, `align-content`, `align-items`, `align-self`, `justify-content` and `order`.

links.title: Article on using the latest spec
Examples on how to solve common layout problems with flexbox
10up Open Sources IE 8 and 9 Support for Flexbox
Ecligrid - Mobile first flexbox grid system
The Difference Between Width and Flex-Basis

flexbox.notes: Most partial support refers to supporting an [older version](https://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-css3-flexbox-20090723/) of the specification or an [older syntax](https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/WD-css3-flexbox-20120322/).

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the [old flexbox](https://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-css3-flexbox-20090723) specification and does not support wrapping.
notes_by_num.2: Only supports the [2012 syntax](https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/WD-css3-flexbox-20120322/)
notes_by_num.3: Does not support flex-wrap, flex-flow or align-content properties
notes_by_num.4: Partial support is due to large amount of bugs present (see known issues)

flexbox-gap.title: gap property for Flexbox
flexbox-gap.description: `gap` for flexbox containers to create gaps/gutters between flex items

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Chrome via the `#enable-experimental-web-platform-features` flag in `chrome://flags`

flow-root.title: display: flow-root
flow-root.description: The element generates a block container box, and lays out its contents using flow layout. It always establishes a new block formatting context for its contents. It provides a better solution to the most use cases of the "clearfix" hack.

links.title: Blog post: "The end of the clearfix hack?"

focusin-focusout-events.title: focusin & focusout events
focusin-focusout-events.description: The `focusin` and `focusout` events fire just before the element gains or loses focus, and they bubble. By contrast, the `focus` and `blur` events fire after the focus has shifted, and don't bubble.

links.title: Mozilla Bug 687787 - Add support for DOM3 focusin/focusout

focusin-focusout-events.notes: In browsers that don't support these events, one alternative is to use a capture phase event listener for the `focus` and/or `blur` events.

font-family-system-ui.title: system-ui value for font-family
font-family-system-ui.description: Value for `font-family` that represents the default user interface font.

notes_by_num.1: Supported as the `-apple-system` value (only on macOS and iOS)
notes_by_num.2: Supported as the `BlinkMacSystemFont` value (only on macOS)

font-feature.title: CSS font-feature-settings
font-feature.description: Method of applying advanced typographic and language-specific font features to supported OpenType fonts.

links.title: Syntax for OpenType features in CSS (Adobe Typekit Help)

font-feature.notes: Whenever possible, font-variant shorthand property or an associated longhand property, font-variant-ligatures, font-variant-caps, font-variant-east-asian, font-variant-alternates, font-variant-numeric or font-variant-position should be used. This property is a low-level feature designed to handle special cases where no other way to enable or access an OpenType font feature exists. In particular, this CSS property shouldn't be used to enable small caps.

notes_by_num.1: From Gecko 2.0 (Firefox 4.0) to Gecko 14.0 (Firefox 14.0) included, Gecko supported an older syntax, slightly different from the modern one: https://hacks.mozilla.org/2010/11/firefox-4-font-feature-support/
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in older Chrome versions refers to lacking support in Mac OS X.

font-kerning.title: CSS3 font-kerning
font-kerning.description: Controls the usage of the kerning information (spacing between letters) stored in the font. Note that this only affects OpenType fonts with kerning information, it has no effect on other fonts.
font-kerning.notes: Browsers with support for [font feature settings](https://caniuse.com/#feat=font-feature) can also set kerning value.

notes_by_num.1: Disabled by default, can be enabled using preference layout.css.font-features.enabled - defaulting to true on Nightly and Aurora only.

font-loading.title: CSS Font Loading
font-loading.description: This CSS module defines a scripting interface to font faces in CSS, allowing font faces to be easily created and loaded from script. It also provides methods to track the loading status of an individual font, or of all the fonts on an entire page.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `layout.css.font-loading-api.enabled` flag. Enabled by default in Firefox 41. See [this bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1149381)

font-size-adjust.title: CSS font-size-adjust
font-size-adjust.description: Method of adjusting the font size in a matter that relates to the height of lowercase vs. uppercase letters. This makes it easier to set the size of fallback fonts.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Does not appear to work on Firefox mobile, despite recognition of the property.

font-smooth.title: CSS font-smooth
font-smooth.description: Controls the application of anti-aliasing when fonts are rendered.

links.title: Old version of W3C recommendation containing font-smooth

font-smooth.notes: Though present in early (2002) drafts of CSS3 Fonts, `font-smooth` has been removed from this specification and is currently not on the standard track.

notes_by_num.1: WebKit implements something similar with a different name `-webkit-font-smoothing` and different values: `none`, `antialiased` and `subpixel-antialiased`.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox implements something similar with a different name `-moz-osx-font-smoothing` and different values: `auto`, `inherit`, `unset`, `grayscale`.
notes_by_num.3: Works only on Mac OS X platform.

font-unicode-range.title: Font unicode-range subsetting
font-unicode-range.description: This @font-face descriptor defines the set of Unicode codepoints that may be supported by the font face for which it is declared. The descriptor value is a comma-delimited list of Unicode range (<urange>) values. The union of these ranges defines the set of codepoints that serves as a hint for user agents when deciding whether or not to download a font resource for a given text run.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

font-unicode-range.notes: Partial support indicates that unnecessary code-ranges are downloaded by the browser - see [browser test matrix](https://docs.google.com/a/chromium.org/spreadsheets/d/18h-1gaosu4-KYxH8JUNL6ZDuOsOKmWfauoai3CS3hPY/edit?pli=1#gid=0).

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `layout.css.unicode-range.enabled` flag

font-variant-alternates.title: CSS font-variant-alternates
font-variant-alternates.description: Controls the usage of alternate glyphs associated to alternative names defined in @font-feature-values for certain types of OpenType fonts.

notes_by_num.1: Low-level syntax available in [font-feature-settings](https://caniuse.com/#feat=font-feature) property equivalent to OpenType features: salt, ss01 through ss20, cv01 through cv99, swsh, cswh, ornm, nalt
notes_by_num.2: Experimental support available by enabling the layout.css.font-features.enabled flag

font-variant-numeric.title: CSS font-variant-numeric
font-variant-numeric.description: CSS property that provides different ways of displaying numbers, fractions, and ordinal markers.

fontface.title: @font-face Web fonts
fontface.description: Method of displaying fonts downloaded from websites
fontface.notes: Not supported by IE Mobile 9 and below.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only supporting EOT fonts.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to only supporting SVG fonts.

form-attribute.title: Form attribute
form-attribute.description: Attribute for associating input and submit buttons with a form.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

form-submit-attributes.title: Attributes for form submission
form-submit-attributes.description: Attributes for form submission that may be specified on submit buttons. The attributes are: `formaction`, `formenctype`, `formmethod`, `formnovalidate`, and `formtarget`

form-validation.title: Form validation
form-validation.description: Method of setting required fields and field types without requiring JavaScript. This includes preventing forms from being submitted when appropriate, the `checkValidity()` method as well as support for the `:invalid`, `:valid`, and `:required` CSS pseudo-classes.

links.title: WebKit Blog: HTML Interactive Form Validation

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to lack of notice when form with required fields is attempted to be submitted.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE10 mobile refers to lack of warning when blocking submission.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Opera Mini refers to only supporting the CSS pseudo classes.

forms.title: HTML5 form features
forms.description: Expanded form options, including things like date pickers, sliders, validation, placeholders and multiple file uploads. Previously known as "Web forms 2.0".

links.title: HTML5 inputs and attribute support page
Cross-browser JS implementation (based on original spec)

fullscreen.title: Full Screen API
fullscreen.description: API for allowing content (like a video or canvas element) to take up the entire screen.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Using Full Screen

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to supporting an earlier draft of the spec.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting `::backdrop`, and supporting the old `:full-screen` syntax rather than the standard `:fullscreen`.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to not returning a Promise, as specified in the latest version of the spec.
notes_by_num.4: Unprefixed support is available behind the `full-screen-api.unprefix.enabled` flag
notes_by_num.5: Partial support refers to supporting only iPad, not iPhone. Shows an overlay button which can not be disabled.

gamepad.title: Gamepad API
gamepad.description: API to support input from USB gamepad controllers through JavaScript.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu

geolocation.title: Geolocation
geolocation.description: Method of informing a website of the user's geographical location

notes_by_num.1: Only works on secure (https) servers

getboundingclientrect.title: Element.getBoundingClientRect()
getboundingclientrect.description: Method to get the size and position of an element's bounding box, relative to the viewport.

notes_by_num.1: The returned object lacks `width` and `height` properties.
notes_by_num.2: Returns incorrect values for elements which have had CSS `transform`s applied to them.
notes_by_num.3: The returned object cannot have new properties added to it; it's not extensible.
notes_by_num.4: Existing properties of the returned object are immutable.
notes_by_num.5: The returned object lacks `x` & `y` values, though existing `top` & `left` values can be used instead.

getcomputedstyle.title: getComputedStyle
getcomputedstyle.description: API to get the current computed CSS styles applied to an element. This may be the current value applied by an animation or as set by a stylesheet.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to requiring the second parameter to be included.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting getComputedStyle on pseudo-elements.

getelementsbyclassname.title: getElementsByClassName
getelementsbyclassname.description: Method of accessing DOM elements by class name

getrandomvalues.title: crypto.getRandomValues()
getrandomvalues.description: Method of generating cryptographically random values.

gyroscope.title: Gyroscope
gyroscope.description: Defines a concrete sensor interface to monitor the rate of rotation around the device’s local three primary axes.

notes_by_num.1: Available by enabling the "Generic Sensor" experimental flag in `about:flags`

hardwareconcurrency.title: navigator.hardwareConcurrency
hardwareconcurrency.description: Returns the number of logical cores of the user's CPU. The value may be reduced to prevent device fingerprinting or because it exceeds the allowed number of simultaneous web workers.

notes_by_num.1: WebKit browsers clamp the maximum value returned to 2 on iOS devices and 8 on all others. Disabled in Safari behind the ENABLE_NAVIGATOR_HWCONCURRENCY build option.

hashchange.title: Hashchange event
hashchange.description: Event triggered in JavaScript when the URL's hash has changed (for example: page.html#foo to page.html#bar)

heif.title: HEIF/ISO Base Media File Format
heif.description: HEIF (High Efficiency Image File Format) is a standard developed by the Moving Picture Experts Group (MPEG) for storage and sharing of images and image sequences. Can use `.heif` or `.heic` file extensions.

notes_by_num.1: While supported natively in macOS High Sierra and iOS 11, the file format does not appear to be supported in Safari.

hevc.title: HEVC/H.265 video format
hevc.description: The High Efficiency Video Coding (HEVC) compression standard is a video compression format intended to succeed H.264

notes_by_num.1: Supported only for devices with [hardware support](https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/insider/forum/insider_apps-insider_wmp/windows-10-hevc-playback-yes-or-no/3c1ab780-a6b2-4b77-ac0f-9faeefd4680d)
notes_by_num.2: Reported to work in certain Android devices with hardware support
notes_by_num.3: Supported only on macOS High Sierra or later

hidden.title: hidden attribute
hidden.description: The `hidden` attribute may be applied to any element, and effectively hides elements similar to `display: none` in CSS.
hidden.notes: The hidden state can be easily overridden with a CSS `display` property set to anything other than `none`.

high-resolution-time.title: High Resolution Time API
high-resolution-time.description: Method to provide the current time in sub-millisecond resolution and such that it is not subject to system clock skew or adjustments. Called using `performance.now()`
high-resolution-time.notes: The timestamp is not actually high-resolution. To mitigate security threats such as Spectre, browsers currently round the result to varying degrees.

notes_by_num.1: In Firefox, the "privacy.reduceTimerPrecision" preference is enabled by default and defaults to 20us in Firefox 59; in 60 it will be 2ms.
notes_by_num.2: In Firefox, the "privacy.resistFingerprinting" preference changes the precision to 100ms or the value of "privacy.resistFingerprinting.reduceTimerPrecision.microseconds", whichever is larger.

history.title: Session history management
history.description: Method of manipulating the user's browser's session history in JavaScript using `history.pushState`, `history.replaceState` and the `popstate` event.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Manipulating the browser history

history.notes: Older iOS versions and Android 4.0.4 claim support, but implementation is too buggy to be useful.

html-media-capture.title: HTML Media Capture
html-media-capture.description: Facilitates user access to a device's media capture mechanism, such as a camera, or microphone, from within a file upload control.

links.title: Correct Syntax for HTML Media Capture
Programming the Mobile Web: File upload compatibility table

notes_by_num.1: iOS6-10 do not support the capture attribute used to force capture straight from the device's camera or microphone. Also note that default video dimensions are 480x320 (4:3).
notes_by_num.2: Android 2.2-2.3 do not support the capture attribute
notes_by_num.3: Supports a "capture" button for any `<input type="file"> field, regardless of the whether the capture attribute is used.

html-media-capture.keywords: htmlmediacapture, html media capture, media capture, mediacapture

html5semantic.title: HTML5 semantic elements
html5semantic.description: HTML5 offers some new elements, primarily for semantic purposes. The elements include: `section`, `article`, `aside`, `header`, `footer`, `nav`, `figure`, `figcaption`, `time`, `mark` & `main`.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to missing the default styling, as technically the elements are considered "[unknown](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLUnknownElement)". This is easily taken care of by manually setting the default `display` value for each tag.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to only the `<main>` element (added later to the spec) being "unknown", though it can still be used and styled.

http-live-streaming.title: HTTP Live Streaming (HLS)
http-live-streaming.notes: HLS can be used with a JavaScript library in browsers that doesn't support it natively as long as they support [Media Source Extensions](/mediasource).

http2.title: HTTP/2 protocol
http2.description: Networking protocol for low-latency transport of content over the web. Originally started out from the SPDY protocol, now standardized as HTTP version 2.
http2.notes: HTTP/2 is only supported over TLS (HTTPS). See also the precursor of HTTP/2, [the SPDY protocol](https://caniuse.com/#feat=spdy), which has been deprecated and removed from most browsers, in favor of HTTP/2.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Internet Explorer refers to being limited to Windows 10.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari refers to being limited to OS X 10.11 El Capitan and newer.
notes_by_num.3: Only supports HTTP/2 if the server supports protocol negotiation via ALPN.

http3.title: HTTP/3 protocol
http3.description: Upcoming version of the HTTP networking protocol, which is currently a draft. Previously known as HTTP-over-QUIC. Uses QUIC as its transport layer protocol.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox via the `network.http.http3.enabled` pref in `about:config`.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled in Chrome(Chromium) via the `--enable-quic` & `--quic-version=h3-23` command line arguments.
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled in Chrome(Chromium) via the `--enable-quic` & `--quic-version=h3-29` command line arguments.
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled in Safari on macOS 11 Big Sur and later in the "Experimental Features" developer menu.

iframe-sandbox.title: sandbox attribute for iframes
iframe-sandbox.description: Method of running external site pages with reduced privileges (e.g. no JavaScript) in iframes.

iframe-seamless.title: seamless attribute for iframes
iframe-seamless.description: The seamless attribute makes an iframe's contents actually part of a page, and adopts the styles from its hosting page. The attribute has been removed from both [the WHATWG](https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/331) and [the W3C](https://github.com/w3c/html/pull/325) HTML5 specifications.

links.title: Microsoft Edge Developer UserVoice: No plans

iframe-seamless.notes: Chrome 20-26 had partial support behind a flag, though this was [later removed](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=229421).

notes_by_num.1: Hides the border of seamless iframes and recognizes the 'seamless' DOM property, but does not provide actual support.

iframe-srcdoc.title: srcdoc attribute for iframes
iframe-srcdoc.description: Override the content specified in the `src` attribute (if present) with HTML content within the attribute.

ime.title: Input Method Editor API
ime.description: Provides scripted access to the Input Method Editor (IME). An IME is often used to input characters from East Asian languages by typing roman characters and selecting from the resulting suggestions.

links.title: Building Better Input Experience for East Asian Users with the IME API in IE11

notes_by_num.1: Prefixed implementation uses `msGetInputContext()` method from an earlier version of the spec to get the `InputMethodContext`, rather than the `inputMethodContext` attribute. Also includes support for `getCompositionAlternatives()` from the latest Editor'

img-naturalwidth-naturalheight.title: naturalWidth & naturalHeight image properties
img-naturalwidth-naturalheight.description: Properties defining the intrinsic width and height of the image, rather than the displayed width & height.

links.title: Blog post on support in IE
gist on getting natural width & height in older IE

import-maps.title: Import maps
import-maps.description: Import maps allows control over what URLs get fetched by JavaScript `import` statements and `import()` expressions.

links.title: Using ES modules in browsers with import-maps

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag at `about:flags`.

imports.title: HTML Imports
imports.description: Deprecated method of including and reusing HTML documents in other HTML documents. Superseded by ES modules.

links.title: HTML5Rocks - HTML Imports: #include for the web
Chromium tracking bug: Implement HTML Imports
Firefox tracking bug: Implement HTML Imports
IE Web Platform Status and Roadmap: HTML Imports

notes_by_num.1: Firefox [has no plans to support HTML imports](https://hacks.mozilla.org/2014/12/mozilla-and-web-components/) though for now it can be enabled through the "dom.webcomponents.enabled" preference in about:config
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "Enable HTML Imports" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.3: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.4: Enabled through the "Enable HTML Imports" flag in opera://flags
notes_by_num.5: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in opera://flags

indeterminate-checkbox.title: indeterminate checkbox
indeterminate-checkbox.description: Indeterminate checkboxes are displayed in a state which is distinct both from being checked or being unchecked. They are commonly used in hierarchical checkboxes to indicate that only some of the checkbox's descendants are checked.

links.title: iOS versions below 12 don't support indeterminate checkboxes (WebKit Bug 160484)

indeterminate-checkbox.notes: Indeterminacy does not affect a checkbox's checkedness state. It merely affects how the checkbox is displayed.

indexeddb.title: IndexedDB
indexeddb.description: Method of storing data client-side, allows indexed database queries.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE 10 & 11 refers to a number of subfeatures [not being supported](https://indexdb-support-test.glitch.me/). Edge does not support IndexedDB inside blob web workers. [See issue](https://web.archive.org/web/20171213082727/https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/5942817/)
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari & iOS 8 & 9 refers to [seriously buggy behavior](http://www.raymondcamden.com/2014/09/25/IndexedDB-on-iOS-8-Broken-Bad/) as well as complete lack of support in WebViews.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support [refers to a bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=226547) in version 14.1.1 that causes indexedDB to never load when the browser is initially opened.

indexeddb2.title: IndexedDB 2.0
indexeddb2.description: Improvements to Indexed DB, including getAll(), renaming stores and indexes, and binary keys.

links.title: Mozilla Hacks: What's new in IndexedDB 2.0?

notes_by_num.1: Missing: IDBKeyRange includes(), renaming stores/indexes, binary keys, IDBObjectStore getKey(), IDBCursor continuePrimaryKey()
notes_by_num.2: Missing: Renaming stores/indexes, binary keys, IDBObjectStore getKey(), IDBCursor continuePrimaryKey()

inline-block.title: CSS inline-block
inline-block.description: Method of displaying an element as a block while flowing it with text.

notes_by_num.1: Only supported in IE6 and IE7 on elements with a display of "inline" by default. [Alternative properties](http://blog.mozilla.com/webdev/2009/02/20/cross-browser-inline-block/) are available to provide complete cross-browser support.

innertext.title: HTMLElement.innerText
innertext.description: A property representing the text within a DOM element and its descendants. As a getter, it approximates the text the user would get if they highlighted the contents of the element with the cursor and then copied to the clipboard.

links.title: WHATWG Compatibility Standard issue #5: spec innerText
Rangy, a JS range and selection library which contains an innerText implementation
Standardizing innerText – Web Incubator Community Group (WICG) discussion

innertext.notes:
This test only checks that the property exists and works correctly in a very simple case.
[This blog post by kangax](http://perfectionkills.com/the-poor-misunderstood-innerText/) explains the history of this property, gives much more detailed cross-browser compatibility information, and gives a detailed strawman specification for the property.
`HTMLElement.innerText` is similar to, but has some important differences from, the standard [`Node.textContent`](https://caniuse.com/#feat=textcontent) property.

input-autocomplete-onoff.title: autocomplete attribute: on & off values
input-autocomplete-onoff.description: The `autocomplete` attribute for `input` elements indicates to the browser whether a value should or should not be autofilled when appropriate.
input-autocomplete-onoff.notes:
This support information does not include support for other `autocomplete` values.

As described in detail below, many modern browsers ignore the `off` value on certain fields in certain cases intentionally in order to give the user more control over autofilling fields. One example is the use of password managers.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to ignoring the `off` value for password fields. [see related blog post](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2009/09/10/troubleshooting-stored-login-problems-in-ie.aspx)
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Chrome refers to the browser intentionally ignoring `autocomplete="off"` when the user uses the browser's autofill functionality. [see bug](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=468153#c29)
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Firefox refers to ignoring `autocomplete="off"` for login forms. [see bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=956906)
notes_by_num.4: Browser does not display previously submitted values as options with `on` value.
notes_by_num.5: Safari ignores the `off` value for [username, email and password fields](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22661977/disabling-safari-autofill-on-usernames-and-passwords)

input-color.title: Color input type
input-color.description: Form field allowing the user to select a color.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Supported through WKWebView and Safari but not through UIWebView

input-datetime.title: Date and time input types
input-datetime.description: Form field widgets to easily allow users to enter a date, time or both, generally by using a calendar/time input widget. Refers to supporting the following input types: `date`, `time`, `datetime-local`, `month` & `week`.
input-datetime.notes: There used to also be a `datetime` type, but it was [dropped from the HTML spec](https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/336).

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Microsoft Edge refers to supporting `date`, `week`, and `month` input types, and not `time` and `datetime-local`.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in iOS Safari refers to not supporting the `week` input type, nor the `min`, `max` or `step` attributes
notes_by_num.3: Some modified versions of the Android 4.x browser do have support for date/time fields.
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `dom.forms.datetime` flag.
notes_by_num.5: Partial support refers to supporting `date` and `time` input types, but not `datetime-local`, `month` or `week`.
notes_by_num.6: Partial support refers to not supporting the `week` and `month` input type

input-email-tel-url.title: Email, telephone & URL input types
input-email-tel-url.description: Text input fields intended for email addresses, telephone numbers or URLs. Particularly useful in combination with [form validation](https://caniuse.com/#feat=form-validation)
input-email-tel-url.notes: Browsers without support for these types will fall back to using the "text" type.

notes_by_num.1: Does not provide an email-specific keyboard for email addresses

input-event.title: input event
input-event.description: The `input` event is fired when the user changes the value of an `<input>` element, `<select>` element, or `<textarea>` element. By contrast, the "change" event usually only fires after the form control has lost focus.

links.title: Specification for `<select>` elements firing the `input` event
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Doesn't fire an `input` event when deleting text (via Backspace, Delete, Cut, etc.).
notes_by_num.2: Doesn't fire an `input` event when drag-and-dropping text into an `<input>` or `<textarea>`.
notes_by_num.3: `<select>` doesn't fire `input` events. See [MS Edge bug](https://developer.microsoft.com/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/4660045/) and [Firefox bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1024350).
notes_by_num.4: Doesn't fire an `input` event when (un)checking a checkbox or radio button, or when changing the selected file(s) of an `<input type="file">`. See [Chrome bug](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=534245), [WebKit bug #149398](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=149398), [WebKit bug #190223](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=190223) and [Firefox bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1206616).
notes_by_num.5: Doesn't fire an `input` event when (un)checking a checkbox or radio button. See [MS Edge bug](https://web.archive.org/web/20160328154136/https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedback/details/1883692/edge-input-of-type-radio-or-type-checkbox-doesnt-fire-input-events).
notes_by_num.6: Doesn't fire an `input` event when changing the selected file(s) of an `<input type="file">`. See [WebKit bug #149398](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=149398) and [WebKit bug #204292](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=204292).

input-file-accept.title: accept attribute for file input
input-file-accept.description: Allows a filter to be defined for what type of files a user may pick with from an `<input type="file">` dialog

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

input-file-accept.notes:
Not supported means any file can be picked as if the `accept` attribute was not set, unless otherwise noted.

On Windows, files that do not apply are hidden. On OSX they are grayed out and disabled.

notes_by_num.1: Supports the type format (e.g. `image/*`) but not the extension format (e.g. `.png`)
notes_by_num.2: Offers appropriate file locations/input based on format type, but does not prevent other files from being selected.
notes_by_num.3: Does not allow any files to be picked at all
notes_by_num.4: Supports the type format but does not allow any file to be picked when using the extension format

input-file-directory.title: Directory selection from file input
input-file-directory.description: The `webkitdirectory` attribute on the `<input type="file">` element allows entire directory with file contents (and any subdirectories) to be selected.
input-file-directory.notes: Lack of support in mobile browsers may be due to the OS file picker not having support for selecting a directory.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu

input-file-multiple.title: Multiple file selection
input-file-multiple.description: Allows users to select multiple files in the file picker.

notes_by_num.1: Not supported on Android 4.x and below, presumably an OS limitation. Only seems to work in Android 5.x for the Chrome browser.

input-inputmode.title: inputmode attribute
input-inputmode.description: The `inputmode` attribute specifies what kind of input mechanism would be most helpful for users entering content into the form control.

links.title: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About inputmode (CSS Tricks)

notes_by_num.1: Support can be enabled via the `dom.forms.inputmode` flag

input-minlength.title: Minimum length attribute for input fields
input-minlength.description: Declares a lower bound on the number of characters a user can input.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

input-minlength.notes: The [`pattern` attribute](https://caniuse.com/#feat=input-pattern) can be used [as an alternative](https://stackoverflow.com/a/10294291) solution for browsers without support.

links.title: Poor browser support for localized decimal marks, commas

notes_by_num.1: Does not support increment/decrement, either via buttons in UI or via arrow up & down keys.
notes_by_num.2: UI widget does not take the "step", "min" or "max" attributes into account.
notes_by_num.3: Firefox doesn't support [autocomplete content via datalist](https://codepen.io/graste/pen/bNoVKW) elements.
notes_by_num.4: Does not include increment/decrement buttons, but does support increment/decrement via arrow up & down keys.

input-pattern.title: Pattern attribute for input fields
input-pattern.description: Allows validation of an input field based on a given regular expression pattern.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - input element: pattern attribute

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not displaying a message for invalid patterns
notes_by_num.2: Safari browsers support the `pattern` attribute but will still allow forms to be submitted if the pattern is incorrect. See the [form validation data](https://caniuse.com/#feat=form-validation) for details.

input-placeholder.title: input placeholder attribute
input-placeholder.description: Method of setting placeholder text for text-like input fields, to suggest the expected inserted information.

links.title: Issue 24626: Placeholder text for an input type=

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to lacking placeholder support on textarea elements.

input-range.title: Range input type
input-range.description: Form field type that allows the user to select a value using a slider widget.
input-range.notes: Currently all Android browsers with partial support hide the slider input field by default. However, the element [can be styled](http://tiffanybbrown.com/2012/02/07/input-typerange-and-androids-stock-browser/) to be made visible and usable.

input-search.title: Search input type
input-search.description: Search field form input type. Intended to look like the underlying platform's native search field widget (if there is one). Other than its appearance, it's the same as an `<input type="text">`.

links.title: Wufoo's The Current State of HTML5 Forms: The search Type

notes_by_num.1: Does not use a special search-specific UI for the field, just the same UI as a regular `<input type="text">`.

input-selection.title: Selection controls for input & textarea
input-selection.description: Controls for setting and getting text selection via `setSelectionRange()` and the `selectionStart` & `selectionEnd` properties.

insert-adjacent.title: Element.insertAdjacentElement() & Element.insertAdjacentText()
insert-adjacent.description: Methods for inserting an element or text before or after a given element, or appending or prepending an element or text to a given element's list of children.

insertadjacenthtml.title: Element.insertAdjacentHTML()
insertadjacenthtml.description: Inserts a string of HTML into a specified position in the DOM relative to the given element.

notes_by_num.1: Throws an "Invalid target element for this operation." error [when called on a table, tbody, thead, or tr element.](https://johnresig.com/blog/dom-insertadjacenthtml/)

internationalization.title: Internationalization API
internationalization.description: Locale-sensitive collation (string comparison), number formatting, and date and time formatting.

intersectionobserver.title: IntersectionObserver
intersectionobserver.description: API that can be used to understand the visibility and position of DOM elements relative to a containing element or to the top-level viewport. The position is delivered asynchronously and is useful for understanding the visibility of elements and implementing pre-loading and deferred loading of DOM content.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Firefox by setting the `about:config` preference `dom.IntersectionObserver.enabled` to true
notes_by_num.2: "Preliminary" support as feature is still in development
notes_by_num.3: `isIntersecting` property of `IntersectionObserverEntry` was not implemented, returning `undefined`
notes_by_num.4: IntersectionObserver does not trigger its callback in a Chrome background tab

intersectionobserver-v2.title: IntersectionObserver V2
intersectionobserver-v2.description: Iteration on the original API that also reports if the element is covered by another element or has filters applied to it. Useful for blocking clickjacking attempts or tracking ad exposure.

links.title: Google Web Docs - Intersection Observer V2

intl-pluralrules.title: Intl.PluralRules API
intl-pluralrules.description: API for plural sensitive formatting and plural language rules.

links.title: Google Developers blog: The Intl.PluralRules API

notes_by_num.1: Intl.PluralRules exists, but methods are not implemented.

intrinsic-width.title: Intrinsic & Extrinsic Sizing
intrinsic-width.description: Allows for the heights and widths to be specified in intrinsic values using the `max-content`, `min-content`, `fit-content` and `stretch` (formerly `fill`) properties.
intrinsic-width.notes:
Prefixes are on the values, not the property names (e.g. -webkit-min-content)

Older webkit browsers also support the unofficial `intrinsic` value which acts the same as `max-content`.
